headline: Scientists find new virus that could infect humans in same way as COVID-19 | Science, Climate & Tech News | Sky News
context: A newly discovered bat coronavirus could at some point spread to humans like COVID-19, Chinese researchers have found.
The virus, HKU5-CoV-2, does not enter human cells as readily as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, the scientists reported in the journal Cell.

annotations.paragraph: However, they found that the bat virus uses the same cell-surface protein, ACE2, as SARS-CoV-2 to help it enter human cells.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about how the new virus could potentially infect humans.

annotations.paragraph: In lab experiments, HKU5-CoV-2 infected human cells with high ACE2 levels in test tubes and in models of human intestines and airways.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details experimental findings that are directly relevant to the virus's potential to infect humans.

annotations.paragraph: Read more science and technology news:How AI is being used to manipulate German votersNew prostate cancer screening trial announcedDonated placenta saved acid attack victim's eye
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a promotional list of unrelated articles and does not contribute to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: In further experiments, the researchers identified antibodies and antiviral drugs that are able to target the bat virus.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about potential treatments for the new virus.

annotations.paragraph: Asked about concerns raised by the report of another pandemic resulting from this new virus, Dr Michael Osterholm, an infectious disease expert at the University of Minnesota, called the reaction to the study "overblown".
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers expert commentary on the potential impact of the new virus, which is relevant to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: He said there is a lot of immunity in the population to similar COVID-19 and SARS viruses compared with 2019.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant context about population immunity related to similar viruses.

annotations.paragraph: The study itself noted that the virus has significantly less binding affinity than SARS-CoV-2.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about the new virus's characteristics.
